G.L. c. 186, \u00a7 14.proposition: Under G.L. c. 186, § 14, a landlord may not “directly or indirectly interfere with the quiet enjoyment of any residential premises by the occupant” by any act or omission, and is liable in damages (including multiple damages) for such interference.

G.L. c. 239.proposition: At all times relevant, Defendant has been a “landlord” within the meaning of G.L. c. 186, § 14 and G.L. c. 239, and has exercised control over repairs and essential building systems at the Premises.

G.L. c. 218, \u00a7 19.proposition: This Court has subject matter jurisdiction over this action pursuant to G.L. c. 218, § 19 and § 19A, because the claims arise under Massachusetts landlord‑tenant law and the amount in controversy is within the jurisdictional limits of the District Court.

G.L. c. 218, \u00a7 19A.proposition: This Court has subject matter jurisdiction over this action pursuant to G.L. c. 218, § 19 and § 19A, because the claims arise under Massachusetts landlord‑tenant law and the amount in controversy is within the jurisdictional limits of the District Court.

G.L. c. 223, \u00a7 2.proposition: Venue is proper in the Brockton Division of the District Court Department pursuant to G.L. c. 223, § 2 and G.L. c. 218, § 19 because the Premises are located in Brockton, and the events giving rise to this action occurred in this division.

Boston Hous. Auth. v. Hemingway, 363 Mas.raw_text: Boston Hous. Auth. v. Hemingway, 363 Mass. 184 (1973)
Boston Hous. Auth. v. Hemingway, 363 Mas.proposition: Under Massachusetts law, every residential tenancy includes an implied warranty of habitability and an implied covenant of quiet enjoyment. See, e.g., Boston Hous. Auth. v. Hemingway, 363 Mass. 184 (1973); G.L. c. 186, § 14.
Boston Hous. Auth. v. Hemingway, 363 Mas.support_reasoning: This opinion (a concurrence/dissent) clearly recognizes that the court is abandoning the old rule of no implied agreement of fitness and is adopting new rules making the landlord’s obligation to maintain habitable premises and the tenant’s obligation to pay rent mutually interdependent. Judge Quirico explicitly describes the majority as creating an implied warranty of fitness/habitability in residential tenancies, and he proposes instead to ground it expressly in statutory and code standards. However, this excerpt does not clearly discuss, or ground its analysis in, the separate implied covenant of quiet enjoyment, so it supports the implied warranty of habitability aspect more directly than the quiet enjoyment aspect.
Boston Hous. Auth. v. Hemingway, 363 Mas.relevant_excerpt: "I agree with the majority of the court that, at least as to dwelling units, the time has come to reconsider the rule so long imbedded in our law of landlord and tenant that ‘[t]here is no implied agreement, apart from fraud, that the demised premises are or will continue to be fit for occupancy or safe and in good repair ... and there is no obligation on the landlord to make repairs.’ ... The opinion of the court accomplishes [making the landlord’s repair/maintenance obligation and tenant’s rent obligation mutually interdependent]."

G.L. c. 111, \u00a7 127A.proposition: Hot water is an essential service and is required in residential rental premises under G.L. c. 111, § 127A and the State Sanitary Code, 105 CMR 410.190 and 410.200, which require landlords to provide a continuous supply of hot water at required temperatures.

105 CMR 410.190.proposition: Hot water is an essential service and is required in residential rental premises under G.L. c. 111, § 127A and the State Sanitary Code, 105 CMR 410.190 and 410.200, which require landlords to provide a continuous supply of hot water at required temperatures.

105 CMR 410.200.proposition: Hot water is an essential service and is required in residential rental premises under G.L. c. 111, § 127A and the State Sanitary Code, 105 CMR 410.190 and 410.200, which require landlords to provide a continuous supply of hot water at required temperatures.

Lowery v. Robinson, 13 Mass. App. Ct. 98.raw_text: Lowery v. Robinson, 13 Mass. App. Ct. 982 (1982)
Lowery v. Robinson, 13 Mass. App. Ct. 98.proposition: Under Massachusetts law, a landlord cannot avoid liability under G.L. c. 186, § 14 by claiming that a contractor, supplier, or third party has delayed repairs, where the landlord retains control of the premises and has the duty to maintain essential services. See, e.g., Lowery v. Robinson, 13 Mass. App. Ct. 982 (1982); Blackett v. Olanoff, 371 Mass. 714 (1977).
Lowery v. Robinson, 13 Mass. App. Ct. 98.support_reasoning: The opinion clearly holds that a landlord’s financial inability to provide heat is not a defense to liability under G.L. c. 186, § 14, focusing on the landlord’s conduct rather than intent or resources. However, it does not discuss situations where delays are caused by a contractor, supplier, or other third party, nor does it address the specific issue of a landlord attempting to shift responsibility to such third parties. Thus, while it supports the broader idea that landlords cannot evade § 14 liability through excuses, it does not specifically support the contractor/supplier-delay aspect of the proposition.
Lowery v. Robinson, 13 Mass. App. Ct. 98.relevant_excerpt: “The tenant correctly argues that the judge erred in declaring that the landlords’ financial inability to purchase oil constituted a defense to the quiet enjoyment claim… It is not necessary to recovery that the landlord intended to violate the covenant. Rather ‘the landlord’s conduct, and not his intentions, is controlling.’… liability will be imposed ‘whenever the “natural and probable consequence” of [the] landlord’s action [is] interruption of the tenant’s rights.’”

Blackett v. Olanoff, 371 Mass. 714 (1977.proposition: Under Massachusetts law, a landlord cannot avoid liability under G.L. c. 186, § 14 by claiming that a contractor, supplier, or third party has delayed repairs, where the landlord retains control of the premises and has the duty to maintain essential services. See, e.g., Lowery v. Robinson, 13 Mass. App. Ct. 982 (1982); Blackett v. Olanoff, 371 Mass. 714 (1977).
Blackett v. Olanoff, 371 Mass. 714 (1977.support_reasoning: Blackett addresses breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment/constructive eviction based on noise from another tenant’s lounge that the landlord had the power to control. It does not involve G.L. c. 186, § 14, essential services, or a landlord’s attempt to excuse noncompliance by blaming delays by a contractor or third party. While it emphasizes landlord liability where the landlord creates a situation and retains control, it does not discuss statutory liability under c. 186, § 14 or excuses based on third‑party delay, so it does not directly support the specific statutory proposition stated.
Blackett v. Olanoff, 371 Mass. 714 (1977.relevant_excerpt: “Because the disturbing condition was the natural and probable consequence of the landlords’ permitting the lounge to operate where it did and because the landlords could control the actions at the lounge, they should not be entitled to collect rent for residential premises which were not reasonably habitable.… To the extent that our opinions suggest a distinction between nonfeasance by the landlord… and malfeasance by the landlord, we decline to perpetuate that distinction where the landlord creates a situation and has the right to control the objectionable conditions.”

105 CMR 410.750.proposition: The continued absence of hot water for a period of approximately three weeks constitutes a serious interference with the health, safety, and comfort of a residential tenant and violates the State Sanitary Code. See 105 CMR 410.190, 410.200, and 410.750; G.L. c. 111, § 127A; see also Berman & Sons, Inc. v. Jefferson, 379 Mass. 196 (1979).

Berman & Sons, Inc. v. Jefferson, 379 Ma.raw_text: Berman & Sons, Inc. v. Jefferson, 379 Mass. 196 (1979)
Berman & Sons, Inc. v. Jefferson, 379 Ma.proposition: The continued absence of hot water for a period of approximately three weeks constitutes a serious interference with the health, safety, and comfort of a residential tenant and violates the State Sanitary Code. See 105 CMR 410.190, 410.200, and 410.750; G.L. c. 111, § 127A; see also Berman & Sons, Inc. v. Jefferson, 379 Mass. 196 (1979).
Berman & Sons, Inc. v. Jefferson, 379 Ma.support_reasoning: The opinion clearly holds that lack of adequate heat and hot water that violates the State Sanitary Code is a material breach of the warranty of habitability and supports rent abatement, but it does not discuss any specific period such as “approximately three weeks,” nor does it characterize a three‑week absence of hot water as a “serious interference” with health, safety, and comfort. The case is cited to show that Sanitary Code violations regarding heat and hot water render a dwelling uninhabitable for warranty/abatement purposes, not to establish any particular duration or to interpret 105 CMR 410.190, 410.200, or 410.750 in terms of a three‑week outage. Thus, the proposition overstates what this case specifically decides.
Berman & Sons, Inc. v. Jefferson, 379 Ma.relevant_excerpt: “The Code puts the landlord on notice that it must supply adequate heat and hot water. State Sanitary Code, Art. II, Regulations 5, 6 (1969) (current version at 105 Code Mass. Regs. 410.190, 410.200, 410.201). … A dwelling afflicted with a substantial Sanitary Code violation is not habitable. The essential objective of the warranty is to make sure that the tenant receives what she is paying for.”

Simon v. Solomon, 385 Mass. 91 (1982).proposition: The covenant of quiet enjoyment is implied by law into Plaintiff’s residential tenancy. See G.L. c. 186, § 14; Simon v. Solomon, 385 Mass. 91 (1982); Blackett v. Olanoff, 371 Mass. 714 (1977).
Simon v. Solomon, 385 Mass. 91 (1982).support_reasoning: The opinion explicitly states the common-law rule that every tenancy includes an implied covenant of quiet enjoyment and links that concept directly to G.L. c. 186, § 14. In discussing § 14, the court explains that the Legislature used the established term “quiet enjoyment” and thereby incorporated the decisional law on the implied covenant of quiet enjoyment into the statute. This squarely supports the proposition that the covenant of quiet enjoyment is implied by law into the plaintiff’s residential tenancy under § 14 and related case law.
Simon v. Solomon, 385 Mass. 91 (1982).relevant_excerpt: “The phrase ‘quiet enjoyment’ is a familiar term in landlord-tenant law, signifying the tenant’s right to freedom from serious interferences with his tenancy — acts or omissions that ‘impair the character and value of the leased premises.’… Every tenancy is deemed to entail an implied covenant that the landlord will not disturb this right during the tenancy. … When the Legislature chose the words ‘quiet enjoyment’ … it must have intended to incorporate these cases into the statute.”

Al-Ziab v. Mourgis, 424 Mass. 847 (1997).proposition: c. Al-Ziab v. Mourgis, 424 Mass. 847 (1997) (sanitary code violations and related conditions can support quiet enjoyment claims);
Al-Ziab v. Mourgis, 424 Mass. 847 (1997).support_reasoning: The case holds that a violation of the lead paint statute, standing alone and without proof of landlord fault, does not constitute a violation of the statutory covenant of quiet enjoyment. While the opinion discusses that negligent failure to repair known defects (including code-related conditions) can violate G.L. c. 186, § 14, it expressly rejects the idea that statutory or regulatory violations by themselves automatically support a quiet enjoyment claim. Thus it does not support the broad proposition that sanitary code violations and related conditions, by their mere existence, can support quiet enjoyment claims.
Al-Ziab v. Mourgis, 424 Mass. 847 (1997).relevant_excerpt: “Today we make clear what was implicit in those rulings: to support the imposition of liability under the quiet enjoyment statute, there must be a showing of at least negligent conduct by a landlord and violation of the lead paint statute alone is not sufficient to prove such negligence. Stated differently, to obtain relief under § 14 for a claim of lead paint poisoning it must be demonstrated that the landlord had notice of or reason to know of the presence of lead and failed to take appropriate corrective measures.”

105 CMR 410.000 et seq..proposition: To the extent necessary, Plaintiff also relies on the statutory and regulatory framework governing minimum standards of fitness for human habitation, including G.L. c. 111, § 127A and 105 CMR 410.000 et seq., as evidence of the uninhabitable and unlawful conditions that give rise to the breach of quiet enjoyment. See Berman & Sons, Inc. v. Jefferson, 379 Mass. 196 (1979); McKenna v. Begin, 5 Mass. App. Ct. 304 (1977).

McKenna v. Begin, 5 Mass. App. Ct. 304 (.raw_text: McKenna v. Begin, 5 Mass. App. Ct. 304 (1977)
McKenna v. Begin, 5 Mass. App. Ct. 304 (.proposition: To the extent necessary, Plaintiff also relies on the statutory and regulatory framework governing minimum standards of fitness for human habitation, including G.L. c. 111, § 127A and 105 CMR 410.000 et seq., as evidence of the uninhabitable and unlawful conditions that give rise to the breach of quiet enjoyment. See Berman & Sons, Inc. v. Jefferson, 379 Mass. 196 (1979); McKenna v. Begin, 5 Mass. App. Ct. 304 (1977).
McKenna v. Begin, 5 Mass. App. Ct. 304 (.support_reasoning: The proposition is that the statutory and regulatory framework for minimum standards of fitness for human habitation (G.L. c. 111, § 127A and the State Sanitary Code, 105 CMR 410.000 et seq.) can be relied upon as evidence of unlawful and uninhabitable conditions giving rise to a breach (here, of quiet enjoyment). McKenna v. Begin directly treats State Sanitary Code violations, adopted under § 127A, as the basis for a breach of the implied warranty of habitability and explains that waiving enforcement of those statutory provisions is impermissible. While McKenna speaks in terms of habitability rather than quiet enjoyment, it clearly treats the Code and its statutory authority as the governing benchmark for habitability and the landlord’s breach, which is analogous support for using that framework as evidence of uninhabitable and unlawful conditions.
McKenna v. Begin, 5 Mass. App. Ct. 304 (.relevant_excerpt: “Under that warranty principle… the judge had awarded damages to the plaintiff McKenna against his landlord… for violations of the State Sanitary Code in the latter’s apartment building, as certified by the Greenfield board of health.” … “Article II of the State Sanitary Code, which established minimum standards of fitness for human occupation in housing, was adopted by the Department of Public Health… under authority granted to it by G. L. c. 111, § 5. That authority is now contained in G. L. c. 111, § 127A…”

G.L. c. 231, \u00a7 6B.proposition: D. Pre‑judgment and post‑judgment interest as allowed by law, including pursuant to G.L. c. 231, § 6B;
